field_edited_text.value:
uture Opportunities

Hawkins Point contains approximately
400 acres of vacant land. There are four
potential development sites in Hawkins
Point:

*Three sites (90 acres, 179 acres, and 30
acres) owned primarily by a subsidiary
of the CSX Railroad.

*Two sites (30 acres and 132 acres) cur-
rently owned by the W.R. Grace Co.
but are to be purchased by the City for
development as a landfill. Lhese sites
will hold some development potential
for light industry, warehousing and
storage operations upon completion of
the landfill operation.

If the three Chessie sites were
marketed to attract industries which
employ an average of 12 persons per acre,
3,600 additional jobs would be created in
Hawkins Point.

Several factors will influence how these
parcels are developed. The CSX Railroad
has expressed an interest in selling land to
rail dependent activities. If this results in
attracting storage and distribution uses, it is
likely that lower levels of employment will
result. The W.R. Grace sites present the
most difficulty in terms of site preparation.
While the other Hawkins Point develop-
ment parcels are relatively flat, W.R.

Grace’s 132-acre southernmost parcel con-
tains a 100-foot-high hill which must be
regraded to allow the landfill to be devel-
oped. One option for regrading would be
to remove the majority of the hill on the
southern site, selling the resulting six

million cubic yards of earth on the open
market and to the Maryland Port Adminis-
tration for fill. To strengthen the market for
the excavated earth, the northern W.R.
Grace parcel could be sold to the Maryland
Port Administration for immediate use as a
dredge spoil disposal site and for long-term
development as a marine terminal capable
of meeting projected port demand beyond
the year 2000. This alternative would result
in a landfill to handle the City’s needs for a
number of years and a 150-acre (30 acres of
existing fastland; 120 acres of fill) site for a
four-berth marine terminal. While this max-
imum excavation approach would be costly
and the completion of the marine terminal
is 25-to-30 years in the future it offers the
following advantages 1) providing more
employment than the minimum excavation
option, 2) partially meeting the Port’s
immediate needs for a dredge disposal site,
3) providing stable fill material for the
Masonville Marine Terminal 4) meeting the
long-term need for additional port terminal
capacity, and, 5) use as a landfill for the
City’s needs.

Vacant land ready for development



In addition to these significant
economic development opportunities,
Hawkins Point contains an important under-
utilized recreation resource in Fort
Armistead. Through a phased improvement
program using special State funds, Fort
Armistead has been made much more
usable to the public. By providing boat
launches, access down the slopes from the
parking lot to the seawall, pathways along
the seawall, landscaping, play areas, and
athletic fields, the City will revive this
neglected facility. Construction was com-
pleted in the summer of 1984.

Fort Armistead, along with the other
forts in the harbor—McHenry, Carroll,
Howard, Smallwood—could also be tied
together by tour boats and offer the citi-
zens of the region a unique recreational
experience. Each fort would be developed
emphasizing a special feature, McHenry
and Carroll historical, Armistead, Small-
wood and Howard recreational. Visitors
could plan part of or an entire day around
the attractions.





52
